recommendation: AVOID codeine. Ultra-rapid metabolism converts codeine to morphine at dangerously high rates, risking life-threatening respiratory depression and toxicity. Use non-opioid analgesics or a non-CYP2D6-metabolized opioid.
Use codeine per standard dosing guidelines. Normal CYP2D6 metabolism expected.
Use codeine with caution at reduced dose. Intermediate metabolism may reduce analgesic efficacy. Consider alternative analgesics if inadequate response.
AVOID codeine. Poor metabolizers cannot convert codeine to morphine — no analgesic effect expected. Use non-CYP2D6-metabolized analgesics (e.g., acetaminophen, morphine, NSAIDs).
AVOID tramadol. Ultra-rapid metabolism increases risk of respiratory depression and seizures. Use alternative analgesics.
Use tramadol per standard dosing guidelines.
Consider reduced dose or alternative analgesic due to decreased O-desmethyltramadol formation.
AVOID tramadol. Lack of active metabolite formation leads to inadequate pain relief. Use non-CYP2D6 analgesics.
Ondansetron may have decreased efficacy due to rapid metabolism. Consider increased dose or alternative antiemetic (e.g., granisetron).
Use ondansetron per standard dosing.
Use ondansetron per standard dosing.
Use ondansetron per standard dosing. May have slightly increased exposure but clinically not significant.
Tamoxifen is effectively metabolized to endoxifen. Standard dosing appropriate.
Use tamoxifen per standard dosing.
Consider higher dose tamoxifen (40mg) or alternative therapy (aromatase inhibitor). Reduced endoxifen formation expected.
AVOID tamoxifen. PM patients produce insufficient endoxifen. Use aromatase inhibitor if postmenopausal, or consider alternative endocrine therapy.
Ultra-rapid metabolizers generate more active metabolite. Standard dosing is appropriate — may have enhanced antiplatelet effect.
Standard dosing of clopidogrel is appropriate.
Standard dosing of clopidogrel is appropriate.
Reduced formation of active metabolite. Consider prasugrel or ticagrelor as alternative antiplatelet therapy if no contraindications.
AVOID clopidogrel. PM patients have markedly reduced active metabolite and diminished antiplatelet response. Use prasugrel or ticagrelor.
Ultra-rapid metabolism may reduce omeprazole efficacy. Consider increasing dose or using rabeprazole (less CYP2C19-dependent).
Consider increased dose for H. pylori eradication or erosive esophagitis.
Standard dosing of omeprazole is appropriate.
Standard dosing of omeprazole. Slightly increased efficacy may be expected.
Consider 50% dose reduction. PM patients have markedly increased omeprazole exposure. Monitor for adverse effects.
AVOID voriconazole if possible. UM patients have sub-therapeutic levels. Use alternative antifungal (e.g., isavuconazole, posaconazole).
Standard dosing of voriconazole. Monitor trough levels.
Standard dosing but higher trough levels expected. Monitor for toxicity.
Use voriconazole with dose reduction and careful therapeutic drug monitoring. PM patients have significantly increased exposure.
Standard warfarin dosing per clinical protocols. Use pharmacogenomic dosing algorithms (e.g., WarfarinDosing.org).
Reduce warfarin starting dose by 25-50%. IM patients have decreased warfarin clearance and increased bleeding risk. Monitor INR closely.
Reduce warfarin starting dose by 50-80%. PM patients have severely impaired warfarin metabolism with high bleeding risk. Frequent INR monitoring required.
Standard phenytoin dosing appropriate.
Reduce phenytoin dose by 25%. IM patients metabolize phenytoin more slowly, increasing toxicity risk. Monitor levels closely.
Reduce phenytoin dose by 50%. Consider alternative anticonvulsant. PM patients accumulate phenytoin, risking severe neurotoxicity.
Standard dosing of fluorouracil/capecitabine is appropriate. Normal DPD enzyme activity expected.
Reduce fluorouracil/capecitabine dose by 50%. Intermediate DPD activity increases risk of severe and potentially fatal toxicity (mucositis, myelosuppression).
AVOID fluorouracil and capecitabine. DPD deficiency causes life-threatening toxicity including severe mucositis, myelosuppression, neurotoxicity, and death. Use alternative chemotherapy.
Standard dosing of capecitabine is appropriate.
Reduce capecitabine dose by 50%. Intermediate DPD activity — risk of severe toxicity.
AVOID capecitabine. DPD deficiency — potentially fatal toxicity.
Standard dosing of azathioprine is appropriate.
Reduce azathioprine dose by 30-80%. IM patients accumulate cytotoxic thioguanine nucleotides — risk of myelosuppression. Monitor CBC.
AVOID azathioprine or use 10% of standard dose with frequent CBC monitoring. Life-threatening myelosuppression expected.
Standard dosing of mercaptopurine is appropriate.
Reduce mercaptopurine dose by 30-80%. Monitor CBC for myelosuppression.
AVOID or use drastically reduced dose (10% of normal). Severe myelosuppression expected.
CYP3A5 expressors require HIGHER tacrolimus doses (1.5-2x standard) to achieve target trough concentrations. Increase starting dose and monitor levels.
May require modestly increased tacrolimus dose. Monitor trough levels closely.
Standard tacrolimus dosing appropriate. Non-expressors have typical drug exposure.
Standard simvastatin dosing. Normal hepatic uptake expected.
Use lower dose simvastatin (max 20mg) or switch to pravastatin/rosuvastatin. Decreased OATP1B1 function increases systemic statin exposure and myopathy risk.
AVOID simvastatin. Use pravastatin or rosuvastatin (not OATP1B1-dependent). Poor function greatly increases risk of statin-induced myopathy and rhabdomyolysis.
Standard atorvastatin dosing appropriate.
Consider lower atorvastatin dose or alternative statin. Monitor for muscle symptoms.
Use lower atorvastatin dose or switch to pravastatin/rosuvastatin. Increased myopathy risk.
